body:
Does the same thing for me. 
Cube-Mac:~ Cube$ jade -w /Users/Cube/Desktop/index.jade 
  rendered /Users/Cube/Desktop/index.html
TypeError: path must be a string
    at Object.fs.lstat (fs.js:676:11)
    at renderFile (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/jade/bin/jade.js:172:6)
    at StatWatcher. (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/jade/bin/jade.js:119:11)
    at StatWatcher.emit (events.js:98:17)
    at StatWatcher._handle.onchange (fs.js:1116:10)
And with respect to testing, I grepped for the `watch` option in the tests, and got nothing back.  Wouldn't be surprised if that's a difficult feature to test properly, though.

Regression since 0266982d. Seems like @ForbesLindesay got confused in the API of  `fs.watchFile()`.

@flintinatux Thanks for the solution. Will commit it shortly.

The API doc recommends using `fs.watch()` over `fs.watchFile()` because it is "more reliable." However, in my tests, this is not the case.

``` js
// test.js
var fs = require('fs')

fs.watch('testfile'
// callback variant
// comment out the next line and uncomment `).on('change',` to test the event API, not it
// would make any difference
, {},
// event API
//).on('change',
function(event, filename) {
  console.log('event: ' + event)
  console.log('filename: ' + filename)
})
```

Output:

``` sh
$ touch testfile
$ node test.js &
$ touch testfile
#> event: change
#> filename: testfile
$ touch testfile
#> event: change
#> filename: testfile

# All good so far

# In another terminal
$ vim testfile
# type :wq<enter>

#> event: rename
#> filename: testfile
#> event: change
#> filename: testfile
#> event: rename
#> filename: testfile
#> event: rename
#> filename: testfile

# WTF???

$ touch testfile
$ touch testfile
$ touch testfile
$ rm testfile
# Now everything is broken
$ fg
$ ^C
```

System info:

``` sh
$ node -v
#> v0.10.25
$ uname -a
#> Linux ubuntu-lenovo 3.13.0-43-generic #72-Ubuntu SMP Mon Dec 8 19:35:06 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ lsb_release -a
#> No LSB modules are available.
#> Distributor ID:  Ubuntu
#> Description: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS
#> Release: 14.04
#> Codename:    trusty
```

BTW, the [documentation](http://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/fs.html#fs_fs_watchfile_filename_options_listener) says:

> If you want to be notified when the file was modified, not just accessed you need to compare `curr.mtime` and `prev.mtime`.

However, on my machine when you `cat` it the callback never fires, so checking `curr.mtime` and `prev.mtime` doesn't make any sense. But, I added it nevertheless for forward compatibility.

issue.title: Some more tests

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug â€“ robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
This PR could really use some more eyes, especially for the watch mode test. I'm kind of anxious of all the child_process hackery/tricks as I'm not that proficient in Node.js.

See also #1795.

body: @flintinatux See #1803 for a rudimentary test for the watch mode. I would appreciate any reviews as I am nervous about all the spawning trickery/hackery.

Just want to thank you for your quick attention to this. I've confirmed it is working as well. Will this be in a 1.8.3 release eventually? No rush, but semester starts on Jan 5th and my Web-2 students usually get thrown into Jade from the very beginning. (We start with basic `npm install -g jade` and then `-w` stuff instead of the other prepros tools and workflows to get a feel for what is happening.)

@robmuh I am sure it will be in 1.8.3, but the release date for 1.8.3 depends entirely on the availability of @ForbesLindesay. BTW, there is a college course for Jade? I would really want to take that class.

Thanks for the info. Not college, our nano-school [SkilStak Coding Arts](http://skilstak.com) where I've been introducing kids as young as 10 to Jade after they get a general feel for HTML/CSS, etc. Jade and Stylus actually make web development easier for these guys because they have started their code lives on Python.
@robmuh Ah ok. I'm just a little bit too old. :)
